title-group.article-title: Patient preferences for adjuvant radiotherapy in early breast cancer are strongly influenced by treatment received through random assignment

aff.named-content: Radiation Oncology Clinical Trials and Research Unit

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Tammy Corica, Radiation Oncology Clinical Trials and Research Unit, Comprehensive Cancer Centre, Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, Nedlands, WA, Australia. Email: Tammy.Corica@health.wa.gov.au

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© 2019 The Authors. European Journal of Cancer Care Published by John Wiley & Sons Ltd

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is nonâcommercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: TARGITâA randomised women with early breast cancer to receive external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) or intraoperative radiotherapy (TARGITâIORT). This study aimed to identify what extra risk of recurrence patients would accept for perceived benefits and risks of different radiotherapy treatments.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Patient preferences were determined by selfârated tradeâoff questionnaires in two studies: Stage (1) 209 TARGITâA participants (TARGITâIORT nÂ =Â 108, EBRT nÂ =Â 101); Stage (2) 123 nonâtrial patients yet to receive radiotherapy (preâtreatment group), with 85 also surveyed postâradiotherapy. Patients tradedâoff risks of local recurrence in preference selection between TARGITâIORT and EBRT.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: TARGITâIORT patients were more accepting of IORT than EBRT patients with 60% accepting the highest increased risk presented (4%â6%) compared to 12% of EBRT patients, and 2% not accepting IORT at all compared to 43% of EBRT patients. Preâtreatment patients were more accepting of IORT than postâtreatment patients with 23% accepting the highest increased risk presented compared to 15% of postâtreatment patients, and 15% not accepting IORT at all compared to 41% of preâtreatment patients.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Breast cancer patients yet to receive radiotherapy accept a higher recurrence risk than the actual risk found in TARGITâA. Measured patient preferences are highly influenced by experience of treatment received. This finding challenges the validity of postâtreatment preference studies.

award-group.funding-source: Cancer and Palliative Care Research and Evaluation Unit
National Health and Medical Research Council

p.mixed-citation: CoricaT, SaundersCM, BulsaraMK, TaylorM, JosephDJ, NowakAK. Patient preferences for adjuvant radiotherapy in early breast cancer are strongly influenced by treatment received through random assignment. Eur J Cancer Care. 2019;28:e1298510.1111/ecc.12985

fn.p: This work was supported by a National Health and Medical Research Council Project Grant (393703), a Cancer and Palliative Care Research and Evaluation Unit Small Project Early Investigator Grant (SG12/002) and a Cancer Council of Western Australia Project Grant (APP1021376).

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Women with early breast cancer must make a number of treatment decisions in conjunction with their treating team. Many of these decisions need patients to weigh up the advantages and disadvantages of treatment options with which they are not familiar, in the context of their individual circumstances, values and wishes. Patients preferring breast conservation surgery receive adjuvant radiotherapy to reduce local recurrence risk; however, external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) is inconvenient, comprising 3â7Â weeks of daily treatments (Early Breast Cancer Trialistsâ Collaborative Group, 2005; Smith etÂ al., 2011). Patients must also consider the potential toxicities of radiotherapy, and sometimes decide to forego radiotherapy (increasing their risk of recurrence) or choose mastectomy to avoid radiotherapy side effects and inconveniences (Boscoe etÂ al., 2011; Collins etÂ al., 2009; NSW Department of Health, 2011; Pan, Smith, & Shih, 2014; Throckmorton & Esserman, 2009).

The introduction of partial breast irradiation now means that patients having breast conservation surgery may need to decide between two radiotherapy options, trading a possible increased risk of local recurrence for a shorter, and hence more convenient, radiotherapy treatment (Vaidya etÂ al., 2014; Veronesi etÂ al., 2010). Targeted intraoperative radiotherapy (TARGITâIORT) delivers radiation directly to the primary tumour bed, during a single session at the time of wide local excision (WLE) or shortly afterwards. The TARGITâA trial randomised women having breast conservation surgery to receive either standard EBRT or intraoperative radiotherapy (TARGITâIORT). At 5Â years after randomisation, more women in the TARGITâIORT arm (2.1%) than the EBRT arm (1.1%) had experienced a local recurrence when IORT was delivered during WLE (before pathology results were available); this difference was not statistically significant and was within the 2.5% preâspecified nonâinferiority margin. However, nonâinferiority could not be established when IORT was delivered as a separate procedure, with local recurrence rates of 5.4% vs. 1.7% for postâpathology IORT and EBRT respectively. (Vaidya etÂ al., 2014, 2015). Patients treated with TARGITâIORT overall had the same breast cancer mortality risk but significantly fewer nonâbreast cancer deaths than those treated with EBRT (1.4% vs. 3.5% pÂ =Â 0.0086) (Vaidya etÂ al., 2014). This finding was supported by a recent metaâanalysis of partial breast irradiation techniques vs. whole breast radiotherapy (Vaidya etÂ al., 2016).

TARGITâIORT has been shown to have less skin toxicity and better patientâreported outcome measures such as pain and cosmetic outcome when compared to EBRT (Keshtgar etÂ al., 2013; Vaidya etÂ al., 2010; Welzel etÂ al., 2013).

When the TARGITâA study began recruiting, the risk of local recurrence following IORT was unknown, as was the level of risk that patients might accept in order to have the more convenient single treatment. We hypothesised that even if TARGITâIORT treatment resulted in a higher risk of local recurrence, a proportion of patients may nevertheless be willing to trade a greater longâterm local recurrence risk for increased shortâterm convenience. We also hypothesised that demographic and social factors including employment status, having dependents, and living further from a treatment centre may influence these patient preferences.

Tradeâoff methodology has been validated for determining patient preferences in oncology (Blinman, King, Norman, Viney, & Stockler, 2012; Blinman etÂ al., 2010, 2011; Duric, Fallowfield etÂ al., 2005; Stiggelbout & de Haes, 2001). Respondents are instructed to consider the positive and negative effects of a treatment together with the probabilities of these effects (Duric & Stockler, 2001; Simes & Coates, 2001). Subjects choose between competing treatment options with differing outcomes (in this case, differing risks of local recurrence), and thus, measure the relative desirability of one treatment option compared with another.

Successful recruitment to TARGITâA demonstrated that treatmentânaÃ¯ve patients were willing to try a more convenient treatment option with an unknown level of risk. This subâstudy was designed to investigate what maximum increase in risk of local recurrence patients would accept to receive TARGITâIORT in place of EBRT, in order to subsequently contextualise the TARGITâA clinical results from a patient perspective.

sec.title: PATIENTS AND METHODS
sec.p: A total of 3,451 patients from 33 centres in 11 countries were recruited into TARGITâA between 2000 and 2012 (ISRCTNâ34086741) (Vaidya etÂ al., 2010, 2014). Patients with early breast cancer suitable for breastâconserving surgery were randomized to receive either a single dose of TARGITâIORT (50Â kV Xârays with INTRABEAM(TM) Carl Zeiss, Oberkochen Germany) or conventional 3â7Â weeks EBRT. TARGITâIORT patients with highârisk pathology as previously described also received EBRT (15%) (Vaidya etÂ al., 2010).

Stageâ1 of this patient preference study was prospectively planned as a subâstudy of the TARGITâA Trial. In 2011, treatment preferences were collected from 213 TARGITâA patients treated at least 3Â months previously as per their allocated randomisation. Participants were reviewed by their Radiation Oncologist for suitability for inclusion in the preference subâstudy. Patients were ineligible if the study would be considered an unwelcome imposition based on social, psychological or other circumstances (FigureÂ 1).

caption.p: CONSORT diagramâStageâ1. IORT: intraâoperative radiotherapy; EBRT: external beam radiotherapy; NESB: nonâEnglish speaking background. *Missing data: questionnaires were returned with key data missing, and attempts to contact patients to retrieve missing data were unsuccessful

sec.p: From 2012 to 2014 preferences were collected from a further 123 usualâcare patients recently diagnosed with breast cancer but yet to receive radiotherapy (Stageâ2). Stageâ2 (preâtreatment group) was developed as a followâup study to test additional hypotheses informed by Stageâ1. In 2015, Stageâ2 participants who had initially been surveyed preâtreatment, and who had not declined further contact, were mailed a second âpostâtreatmentâ questionnaire. Human research ethics approvals were obtained for all studies and all participants provided written informed consent.

sec.title: Stageâ1, TARGITâA group
sec.p: TARGITâA participants were mailed an invitation letter with an optâout card. Patient preference, demographics and the Patient Disease And Treatment Assessment (Patient DATA) questionnaires utilised in previous preference studies were adapted for this study and were mailed to patients who did not opt out (Supporting Information Appendices [Link], [Link], [Link]) (Blinman etÂ al., 2010; Duric, Stockler, etÂ al., 2005; Simes & Coates, 2001). The questionnaire method of eliciting patient preferences has been validated through prospective comparison to scripted faceâtoâface methodology (Blinman etÂ al., 2010).

The preference questionnaire was used to determine the largest 5âyears recurrence risk that women considered acceptable in return for the shorter duration and altered toxicity profile of TARGITâIORT. Participants were asked to imagine they knew what their risk of local recurrence would be with conventional EBRT. They were then asked to determine the maximum increased risk of local recurrence they would accept in order to receive TARGITâIORT. Risk of recurrence of EBRT was represented as 3% in Question 1, 6% in Question 2, then as 3/100 in Question 3 and 6/100 in Question 4 (Supporting Information Appendix S1).

Acknowledging that an event such as treatment for breast cancer may alter some variable patient characteristics, such as work status, where appropriate the demographics questionnaire was answered for three separate time points: âbefore breast cancer,â âduring breast cancer treatmentâ and ânowâ (being the time of questionnaire completion) (Supporting Information Appendix S2).

The patient DATA form consists of 22 questions which are scored from 0 (no trouble at all) to 10 (Worst Imaginable) by participants to indicate the extent to which different aspects of their treatment troubled them. Participants were instructed to recall symptoms during radiotherapy treatment. The scores are grouped as shown in Supporting Information Appendix S3.

sec.title: Stageâ2, preâtreatment group
sec.p: Potential participants were identified during multidisciplinary team meetings, and the study was discussed by the attending surgeon. Interested patients were telephoned by the study coordinator who then mailed out questionnaires to those who agreed to participate. The preference questionnaire was modified slightly for the preâtreatment setting (Supporting Information Appendix S4). Stageâ1 participants had demonstrated a preference for risk presented as a proportion; hence, the questions represented as percentages were removed. This allowed an alternative preference scenario to be examined: TARGITâIORT being delivered either during WLE, or as a second procedure. Demographics were also collected. Participants who agreed to further contact were mailed a second questionnaire 1Â year later, to capture preferences âpostâtreatment.â

sec.title: Analysis and interpretation
sec.p: Statistical significance was set at pÂ <Â 0.01 to account for multiple comparisons (Bland & Altman, 1995; Bottomley etÂ al., 2004). IBMâSPSSâV23 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) was used for all analyses. The Kappa statistic was used to determine reliability between percentage and proportion based questions and between the two baseline levels of recurrence risk presented. Kappa scores were interpreted based on levels of agreement described by Landis and Koch; <0 Poor, 0.0â0.20 Slight, 0.21â0.40 Fair, 0.41â0.60 Moderate, 0.61â0.80 Substantial, 0.81â1.00 Almost perfect (Landis & Koch, 1977). Nonâparametric Wilcoxon SignedâRank (paired) tests were used to test differences between responses for TARGITâIORT as a separate procedure vs. TARGITâIORT delivered during WLE, and between the preâtreatment vs. postâtreatment preference setting. Multivariate and univariate Poisson regression was utilised to test potential predictors of patient preference.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: A total of 336 consecutive TARGITâA participants were reviewed for suitability, and exclusions are shown in FigureÂ 1. Two hundred and thirteen evaluable responses were received; 108 had received TARGITâIORT, 101 had received EBRT and four had received both TARGITâIORT and EBRT.

A total of 151 standard care patients were invited to participate in Stageâ2 (preâtreatment preference study), with 123 evaluable questionnaires received. The âpostâtreatmentâ questionnaire was mailed to 119 of the 123 initial participants with 85 returned (FigureÂ 2).

caption.p: CONSORT diagramâStageâ2

sec.p: Demographics were similar across all groups, although Stageâ2 patients were slightly younger, had more child dependents, and higher levels of education and employment than Stageâ1 participants (TableÂ 1). These factors were considered in single and multivariate analysis of patient preference (Supporting Information Appendix S5).

caption.p: Demographics

fn.p: EBRT: external beam radiotherapy; IORT: intraoperative radiotherapy; PreâRx: Preâtreatment (preâradiotherapy).
aWhere stayed during radiotherapy.bWhere stayed during surgery.

sec.p: TARGITâIORT patients recalled fewer symptom concerns during treatment than EBRT patients across all Patient DATA form questions. Significant (pÂ â¤Â 0.01) differences were found in seven of 22 questions, with TARGITâIORT patients recalling fewer problems with fatigue, energy levels, skin problems, breast sensitivity, treatment convenience, coping with treatment and being able to do the things they wanted (Supporting Information Appendix S6). These factors were considered in single and multivariate analysis of patient preference (Supporting Information Appendix S5).

sec.title: Preference results
sec.p: FigureÂ 3 illustrates averaged preference scores in four ordinal categories for each patient group. In Stageâ1, patients who had received TARGITâIORT through random assignment were less riskâaverse than those who had received EBRT with 60% vs. 12% accepting IORT at the 4%â6% increased risk level, 31% vs. 26% at the 1%â3% increased level, 7% vs. 20% if equivalent to EBRT and 2% vs. 43% not finding it acceptable at all (âneverâ). In Stageâ2, preâtreatment patients were less riskâaverse than postâtreatment patients with 23% vs. 15% accepting IORT at the 4%â6% increased risk level, 43% vs. 26% at the 1%â3% increased level, 20% vs. 18% if equivalent to EBRT and 15% vs. 41% not finding it acceptable at all (âneverâ) (FigureÂ 3).

caption.p: Averaged maximum acceptable increased risk. IORT: Patients received TARGITâIORT on the TARGITâA Trial (Stageâ1); EBRT: Patients received EBRT on the TARGITâA Trial (Stageâ1); PreâRx: Patients completed preference questionnaire prior to any radiotherapy (Stageâ2); PostâRx: Patients completed the preference questionnaire after radiotherapy (Stageâ2); High Risk: Would accept IORT if local recurrence was 4%â6% higher than EBRT; Low Risk: Would accept IORT if local recurrence was 1%â3% higher than EBRT; Equivalent: Would only accept IORT if local recurrence was equivalent to EBRT; Never: Would never accept IORT

sec.p: With 23% of the Stageâ2 preâtreatment respondents accepting TARGITâIORT at the 4%â6% increased risk, they were more riskâaverse than Stageâ1 TARGITâIORT patients (60%) but less riskâaverse than the Stageâ1 patients who had completed EBRT following random assignment (12%).

However, after Stageâ2 participants had completed treatment, their responses changed to more closely approximate Stageâ1 postâEBRT responses (15% and 12% accepting 4%â6% increased risk respectively). Overall acceptance (those not selecting âneverâ) of TARGITâIORT was 98% for the Stageâ1 postâTARGITâIORT group, 58% for the Stageâ1 postâEBRT group, 86% for the Stageâ2 preâtreatment group and 59% for the Stageâ2 postâtreatment group.

The only significant characteristic impacting preference in Stageâ1 was the treatment patients had received on the TARGITâA Trial (TARGITâIORT or EBRT; pÂ =Â <0.001, mean difference 2.5). This remained unchanged when controlling for other potential drivers of treatment preference.

In the preâtreatment Stageâ2 participants, no significant relationship was observed between preference outcomes and demographics. Postâtreatment, having child dependents was a weak predictor for greater acceptance of TARGITâIORT as a separate procedure (pÂ =Â 0.006) in multivariate analysis, but this was not significant for IORT during WLE (pÂ =Â 0.019). Stageâ2 patients were more accepting of TARGITâIORT preâtreatment than they were postâtreatment (Wilcoxon signedârank test pÂ <Â 0.001).

sec.title: Analyses specific to the TARGITâA group (Stageâ1)
sec.p: Twentyâsix percentage of participants preferred risk represented as a percentage, 56% preferred a proportion out of 100% and 15% had no preference.

Multivariate and univariate analysis revealed no significant differences in patient characteristics over the different time points used in the demographics questionnaire (âbefore breast cancer,â âduring treatmentâ and ânowâ), hence only the ânowâ data were used in the final analysis.

sec.title: Analyses specific to the preâtreatment group (Stage 2)
sec.p: TableÂ 2 shows patient, tumour and treatment characteristics of Stage 2 participants with 60% meeting the âlow riskâ criteria used for TARGITâA in Australia (<2Â cm tumours, Grade 1â2, clear margins, hormone receptor positive, node negative, ductal (not lobular), negative for extensive intraductal component or lymphovascular invasion) (Vaidya etÂ al., 2010). 82% of Stageâ2 participants subsequently received conventional 6âweek EBRT, 15% received hypofractionated (3â4Â week) EBRT and 2% received TARGITâIORT. If all treatment modalities offered equivalent outcomes, 13% of preâtreatment patients chose EBRT, 25% chose TARGITâIORT as a separate procedure and 62% chose TARGITâIORT during WLE as their preferred option (FigureÂ 4). After the patients had completed treatment, acceptability of EBRT increased to 29% but decreased for the TARGITâIORT options to 15% for TARGITâIORT separate to WLE and 55% for TARGITâIORT during WLE (paired t test pÂ =Â 0.013, mean difference 0.24). Overall, 87% of patients who had not yet had radiotherapy accepted TARGITâIORT over EBRT, and this proportion decreased to 70% after patients had received treatment.

caption.p: Tumour and treatment characteristics of preâtreatment group

fn.p: EBRT: external beam radiotherapy; IORT: intraoperative radiotherapy.

aPatient and tumour characteristics were within the eligibility criteria for TARGITâA in Australia (<20Â cm tumours, Grade 1â2, clear margins, hormone receptor positive, node negative, ductal (not lobular), negative for extensive intraductal component or lymphovascular invasion). bRadiotherapy details were only collected from patients providing a postâtreatment questionnaire.

caption.p: Preferred treatment optionâStageâ2. EBRT: external beam radiotherapy; IORT: intraoperative radiotherapy; WLE: wide local excision

sec.p: There was no difference in preferences when patients were presented with alternative scenarios of IORT as a separate procedure or during WLE at either level of baseline recurrence risk (Wilcoxon signedârank test pÂ =Â 0.338 and 0.335 respectively) for preâtreatment or postâtreatment groups (pÂ =Â 0.216 and 0.624 respectively).
Participants could opt to leave free text comments on the final page. This data are described in Supporting Information Appendix S7.

sec.title: DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION
sec.p: Patient preference studies are increasingly recognised as an important secondary, and in some cases primary, outcome in health care research. This preference study utilised validated questionnaire methodology in two sequential studies, each with two patient cohorts; Stageâ1 included patients who had already received either TARGITâIORT or EBRT on the TARGITâA trial and Stageâ2 included breast cancer patients yet to receive radiotherapy, most of whom were surveyed again postâtreatment.

The most striking finding of this research was the discovery that preferences elicited in the postâtreatment setting yield very different results to those elicited in the preâtreatment setting. This study, in which preferences were first elicited from patients who had completed treatment with one of two radiotherapy modalities to which they had been randomly assigned, demonstrated that the most important determinant of treatment preference was the treatment already experienced by that patient. Despite patients having entered the trial accepting a 50% chance of randomisation to either radiotherapy technique, those who had been randomised to TARGITâIORT strongly favoured the treatment they had received, even at a hypothetical increased risk of recurrence compared to the EBRT group. Furthermore, 43% of patients who had been randomised to and received EBRT indicated they would not accept TARGITâIORT at all. The only plausible explanation for this, in patients with similar characteristics who had provided informed consent to randomisation to either treatment, is that patients were justifying the treatment they had received, therefore indirectly justifying their decision to participate in the randomised trial, thus potentially avoiding decisional regret. Optional comments made by Stageâ1 participants demonstrated that as their experience with the treatment they had received on the randomised study was acceptable to them, they were biased towards that treatment when completing the preference questionnaire. There were very few comments suggesting that the recalled toxicities of treatment impacted treatment preferences. Analysis of the Patient DATA form confirmed this; despite TARGITâIORT patients reporting significantly fewer treatment side effects, none of these factors were determinants of preferences after treatment. Time since treatment did not impact preference results in Stageâ1; however, treatment had been completed 4â85Â months prior to completion of the Patient DATA form which is likely to have introduced some level of recall bias.

This preference study originally set out to identify what hypothetical level of increased risk of local recurrence patients would accept in order to choose a new, more convenient treatment option (TARGITâIORT) over conventional EBRT. Preferences varied across all four patient groups, with the least riskâaverse group being those who had received TARGITâIORT on the TARGITâA study (98% overall acceptance of IORT, and 60% accepting it at the highest increased risk presented which was 4%â6%), and the most riskâaverse groups being the TARGITâA EBRT group and the postâtreatment Stageâ2 participants (27%â29% overall acceptance of IORT, with 12%â15% accepting it at the highest risk presentedâ4%â6%). The Stageâ2 preâtreatment group demonstrated intermediate preferences, with 85% overall acceptance of IORT and 23% accepting it at the highest risk presented, 4%â6% increase in local recurrence. These preference results showed that around a third of patients were willing to accept TARGITâIORT at a higher risk than that which was observed in the TARGITâA trial, which found nonâsignificant absolute increases in risk of recurrence of 1% in the group having IORT during WLE and 3.7% in the group having IORT as second separate procedure. Although IORT during WLE is the recommended approach, it is not always feasible. These results suggest that some women, at least before they have experienced treatment, may accept a risk of recurrence in keeping with the results of TARGITâA in order to receive IORT as a separate procedure, if immediate IORT is not possible. The results of this study therefore provide a further discussion point for providers when considering obstacles to radiotherapy access, especially for patients in rural and remote areas. If health professionals and informed patients accept the small additional risk of local recurrence for a more convenient treatment schedule, then it may be considered an option for suitable patients, and would be preferable to forgoing radiotherapy due to the inconvenience of EBRT.

That treatment experience would be the only important determinant of retrospective patient preference in a randomised population was not anticipated when this research began. The only previous preference study of adjuvant radiotherapy following breastâconserving surgery, and indeed most previous preferences research, had been conducted following more homogeneous treatment (Duric, Stockler, etÂ al., 2005; Hayman, Fairclough, Harris, & Weeks, 1997). The methodology and timing of administration of Stage 1 of this study was therefore based on these prior validated studies; furthermore, the validity of the paperâbased questionnaire methodology had also been established (Blinman etÂ al., 2010). Our results from Stage 1 of the study are the first to question the validity of eliciting preferences postâtreatment and to identify the potential role of avoidance of decisional regret. There was no indication that other aspects of the discrete choice methodology, or the use of a paperâbased questionnaire, were less valid in this population than in prior studies. A concurrent study of patient preferences for TARGITâIORT in the USA reported that 91% of patients found TARGITâIORT acceptable, with a median increase in acceptable risk of 2.3% (Alvarado etÂ al., 2014). This is comparable to the âlow increased riskâ category (a 1%â3% increase) in the present study which was acceptable to 91% of the TARGITâIORT group, 38% of the TARGITâEBRT group, 66% of the preâtreatment group and 41% of the postâtreatment group. However, in that study, combined results were reported from 21 preâtreatment and 60 postâtreatment patients. Results from our larger study question the appropriateness of combining these groups.

Another study investigating preferences for adjuvant chemotherapy (ACT) after early breast cancer showed stability of preferences before and after treatment; however importantly, these patients had selected their treatment, rather than being randomised (Jansen etÂ al., 2001).

Our results challenge the utility of eliciting patient preferences postâtreatment in a randomised controlled trial. This population does not represent the knowledge base of treatmentânaÃ¯ve patients, and results may be significantly biased by the avoidance of decision regret, albeit an unconscious bias, in patients who have completed treatment. This interpretation is supported by a recent preference study in patients with endometrial cancer who were randomised to receive ACT vs. no ACT. Preferences were elicited both after randomisation but before treatment, and 9Â months later (after treatment) (Blinman etÂ al., 2016). Findings were similar to our study, with patients who had received ACT requiring smaller benefits to accept ACT than those who did not receive it, and less benefit required postâtreatment than preâtreatment. These results suggest that the actual experience of ACT treatment may have been better than anticipated, or that preferences justified participation in the randomised trial and avoided decision regret. These results also explain the surprising finding that some women will accept almost zero benefit for ACT for early breast cancer when preferences are elicited after treatment (Duric & Stockler, 2001; Duric, Stockler, etÂ al., 2005; VazâLuis etÂ al., 2017).

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: In terms of the primary goal of this research, we found that women who had yet to receive radiotherapy for early breast cancer indicated that TARGITâIORT was an acceptable treatment option, with the majority of patients also willing to accept a higher risk of recurrence in order to have the more convenient treatment option. The most striking finding of this research was however the incidental discovery that preferences elicited postâtreatment are significantly biased by the experience of treatment received. Preferences elicited postâtreatment appear instead to be an indirect method of eliciting patient satisfaction of treatment already received, and therefore offer a biased account of preference, rather than a consumer perspective of all potential treatments on offer. The results of our study strongly challenge the use and interpretation (and thus the validity) of postâtreatment preference studies. We recommend that both qualitative (Duric, Fallowfield, etÂ al., 2005; Jansen etÂ al., 2001) and quantitative preâtreatment patient preference studies are utilised in future research, together with postâtreatment preferences and measurements of treatment satisfaction and/or decision regret.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: Carl Zeiss sponsored some of the travel for meetings of the international steering committee and when necessary for conferences where a presentation about TARGITâA was being made. Carl Zeiss had no involvement in this publication.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: The investigators would like to thank all TARGITâA SubâStudy participants, as well as local clinicians and research coordinators for their involvement in the study. The early support and guidance from Dr Vlatka Duric, Professor Martin Stockler, and Dr Prunella Blinman from the NHMRC Cancer Trials Centre is also greatly appreciated.
